More The Chantoozies

When The Chantoozies emerged from Melbourneâs nightclub scene in 1987 with a top 5 remake of Witch Queen and followed it a year later with self-penned smash Wanna Be Up, they established themselves as one of Australiaâs top pop acts and earned industry cred for their relentless touring schedule.

Notable at the time was their large line-up: four female singers (Tottie Goldsmith, Ally Fowler, Eve von Bibra and Angie La Bozzetta) and four male band members (David Reyne, Brett Goldsmith, Scott Griffiths and Frank McCoy).

âThere were a lot of personalities, a lot of opinions,â Brett Goldsmith said in a new two-part special of podcast A Journey Through Aussie Pop.

By the time of their final hit, a cover of Love The One Youâre With in 1991, the group had been reduced to an all-girl trio. In the podcast, the seven surviving members of The Chantoozies â McCoy passed away in 2021 â explain how eight became three. And itâs a topic that hasnât ever been fully discussed among the band members, who are all still on good terms with each other.

On A Journey Through Aussie Pop, Tottie Goldsmith, Griffiths and Reyne explained their various reasons for leaving after The Chantooziesâ self-titled debut album had been released.

âI didnât think we were on the same page, and it was starting to get bitchy,â Tottie said of her decision to jump ship first. âAlso, I felt like I had so much more to offer creatively.â

Griffiths, who was the most experienced and gifted musician in the band, wanted to return to his musical education and found the experience of being in a pop group not for him.

As for Reyne, who would return to TV work after the band with a role in The Flying Doctors, the simmering tensions among some of the band members got too much for him.

âI spent so much time calming everything downâ¦ and sorting things out and getting everyone on the same page,â he recalled. âI got exhausted from being the diplomat in the band.â

But it was the decision to sack Brett Goldsmith and McCoy and have Fowler, von Bibra and La Bozzetta continue as a three-piece that is the elephant in the room that hasnât previously been spoken about.

âThe record company approached us and said, âWe think this would work better with just the three of you,ââ Fowler said. âFirst of all, they were our friends and we loved them dearly. And secondly, I remember us being a bit worried about messing with the formula. Look, they probably thought it was going to be easier to handle the three of us.â

Von Bibra added: âIt was just, âI guess if we want to stay doing this, this is what theyâre recommending.ââ

La Bozzetta (now Arnott) revealed another factor: that the split between what the guys and the girls wanted had reached breaking point and âit was just timeâ to make the change. âI donât think we handled that as maturely as we probably could have. We kind of handed it over to our manager at the time. We should have really been a bit more diplomatic. I cried, I was really sad â I didnât like doing it.â

The Chantoozies past and present â Fowler and von Bibra continue to perform and record under the bank moniker â also explained a few other mysteries concerning their time in the spotlight. For one thing, how the head-to-head battle between The Chantoozies and The Party Boys with rival versions of Heâs Gonna Step On You Again came about. Also, why the bandâs song Slightest Notion was also released by James Reyne as Motorâs Too Fast. And the existence of two romances among the band members are revealed.
